reqs:
Please note: PHIL 101 and PHIL 102 are independent introductory courses and need not be taken in sequential order.
This course offers an introduction to philosophy through an exploration of various practical puzzles and paradoxes found in contemporary moral philosophy, value theory, and decision theory. These include: the nature of morality, the trolley problem, the problem of moral luck, the non-identity problem, Parfits repugnant conclusion, the prisoners dilemma, and Newcombs paradox. No prior familiarity with philosophy is required for this course.

Please note: PHIL 101 and PHIL 102 are independent introductory courses and need not be taken in sequential order. Instructor: Irwin Chan

description: Basic problems and methods of philosophy. Topics such as morality, personal identity, free will and determinism, and the meaning of life. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 100 or PHIL 102.
